recipes: Find work which will spare my body, if not my mind.
Glover & Glover have offered me a junior position. I start at eight sharp, tomorrow morning!
The scratching of pens, the sourness of dust, the sighing of the younger Glover, the greedy gurgling of the elder.
The clerks file out in silence. I am free for now.
(I could devote extra effort to the work...)
Extra effort. It might help, sometimes.
I will work whatever overtime is required. Perhaps they'll appreciate it.
(Is this all I am meant for?)

Mr Alden, the Supervisor of Records, has called me into his office to recognise my diligence. I watch the mole on his neck as he talks; and talks; and talks. But at the end of it, I have a promotion!
		
My new position is better paid, and the desk stands by the street window. But I work directly for Mr Alden now. Mr Alden is known to be exacting.

I am better-paid than I was. But Mr Alden has taken an interest in me. Mr Alden is very particular. Mr Alden likes things done just so. And Mr Alden has never believed that I am qualified for this position.
Mr Alden has found nothing to criticise in my work, today. He does not look up as I leave.
'I shall be leaving Glover & Glover tomorrow. When you've finished your work for the day, come and see me.'

'Under my direction, you have shown some improvement. I have recommended you as my replacement. Remember what I have taught you, and you might one day be a credit to this department. You may go.'
	
'One more thing! I had almost forgotten - '
	
'Be especially punctual tomorrow, please.'
Work overtime, at Mr Alden's insistence
'The work is complete when I have assessed the work as complete, and not before. I trust we understand each other.'
Extra effort. It might help, if I'm very lucky.

'On this occasion I have determined that your work is of an acceptable standard. I will even authorise an additional payment, although naturally it will be a modest one. You may go. Be punctual tomorrow, please.'
	
[There may be ways to deal with Mr Alden.]
Work overtime, at Mr Alden's insistence
'I do not believe that you have properly understood the importance of our work here. This task will require your full attention.' [Add Reason or Passion to satisfy Mr Glover.]

'I would like to say that I am disappointed, but my expectations of you were already low. I have no choice but to withhold a portion of your pay. You may go, but be punctual tomorrow, please.'
	
[There may be ways to deal with Mr Alden.]

The office crackles with the news of Alden's unexpected absence. A scrawny, nervous fellow from the fourth floor has been appointed Supervisor of Record (Temporary). Unlike Alden, he does not interfere with my work.
Ink, paper, and the fizzing of the electric lights. The office is dark when I leave. But I leave at the appointed time.
I work longer hours now, but they're better-paid.
Ink, paper, and the fizzing of the electric lights. The office is dark when I leave. Outside on the pavement, I turn up my collar.
(I could devote extra effort to the work...)

recipes: The younger Glover has taken me out for a lunch at his club. I am to do more of the things that I do, more carefully, and in return, he will give me a little more of the money I earn for him.
Curl my hands into the correct shapes, and begin.
I am always the last to leave, even after the elder Glover.
(I could devote extra effort to the work...)
I could devote my life to this.
There is a dank and clinging smell to the Institute halls that never quite leaves one. Perhaps it is the paint. Perhaps it is the patients. Perhaps it is something in the walls.
I have done some good. My patients are quieter than when I began.
Back-breaking work for meagre pay. Is this the best I can do?
The day is done, and so am I; but I've earned my pay.
Back-breaking work for meagre pay. Is this the best I can do?
The day is done, and so am I; but I've earned my pay.
I'm injured! I'll hobble painfully home with my wretched pay.
I have seen a curious beauty in the waking world, and in my dreams. I might sell a painting. I probably won't.
I've finished a painting, to the excitement of absolutely no-one: no-one but me.
I've found a customer! She'll probably hang it in her spare bedroom and never look at it again. But her money is good.
I recall something of the architecture of dreams...
Daylight should not touch this canvas. I'll get in trouble.
This does nothing; but perhaps I might eventually find another way to invest my funds in my future. If I have a future.
My investments will provide well for me, if I pay attention to them.
A neat white cheque in a neat white envelope, for a handsome sum.
My investments will provide sufficiently for me, if I pay attention to them.
A neat white cheque in a neat white envelope, for a reasonably attractive sum.
My investments will just about provide for me, if I pay attention to them.
A neat white cheque in a neat white envelope, for a modest sum.
I have received the usual cheque, but it comes with disquieting news. My investments have suffered - ill luck, or, just possibly, an enemy's malice.
